Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
Staff person 1 did not engage Resident A and complete the intake in a professional
manner. During the intake staff were also heard outside of the room using profanity
and racial slurs.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident A
I interviewed Resident A in person on 07/28/2020. I asked Resident A if he had
concerns with his intake process at Clarence Fischer Center. Resident A replied he
did not have any concerns. I asked Resident A about the personal items he brought
to the facility. Resident A stated Department of Health and Human Service worker 1
and 2 took most of his personal belongings since he was not allowed to keep it.
Resident A stated he kept some of his personal items, such as, body wash and
phone charger but not his cell phone. I asked Resident A if he heard staff talking and
using profanity during his intake. Resident A stated Staff person 1 did not use
profanity but he heard profanity from the staff in the multipurpose room. Resident A
denied hearing ethnic slurs.
Department of Health and Human Service worker 1
I interviewed Department of Health and Human Service (DHHS) worker 1 on
07/22/2020 by telephone. DHHS worker 1 stated she and DHHS worker 2 took
Resident A to Clarence Fischer Center on 07/14/2020 and arrived there at 9:49 pm.
DHHS worker 1 stated Resident A had 3 duffel bags and 2 suitcases and Clarence
Fischer Center staff did not greet them or offer to help bring in Resident A’s
belongings. DHHS worker 1 stated Staff person 1 escorted them to a side room off
of the multipurpose room for the intake. DHHS worker 1 stated Staff person 1 asked
Resident A to share his abuse and neglect history and his suicide attempt history.
DHHS worker 1 stated she intervened and told Staff person 1 the information was in
the referral packet but Staff person 1 stated he was required to ask. DHHS worker 1
stated Staff person 1 informed Resident A he could only keep one bag of personal
items and law enforcement would be called if he needed to be restrained at the end
of the interview. DHHS worker 1 stated during the intake she heard staff in the
multipurpose room laughing, talking, and using profanity.
Department of Health and Human Service worker 2
I interviewed Department of Health and Human Service (DHHS) worker 2 by
telephone on 07/23/2020. DHHS worker 2 stated she and DHHS worker 1
transported Resident A to Clarence Fischer Center on 07/14/2020. DHHS worker 2
stated upon their arrival there was confusion on who would complete Resident A’s
intake. DHHS worker 2 stated no one welcomed Resident A and assisted Resident
A in what personal belongings he could keep at the facility. DHHS worker 2 stated
3

Staff person 1 said it did not matter what personal clothes Resident A kept because
he would be given a jumpsuit. DHHS worker 2 stated staff were clocking in and out
and talking loudly and using profanity in the multipurpose room outside of the intake
interview room.
Staff person 1
I interviewed Staff person 1 in person on 07/28/2020. Staff person 1 stated his shift
started at 10 pm on 07/14/2020 but he punched in early to facilitate Resident A’s
intake because Staff person 2 and 3 were leaving soon. Staff person 1 stated the
intake process was not smooth because the phone rang, and he had to inform third
shift staff which unit to work. Staff person 1 stated he introduced the shelter program
by describing the sleeping arrangements to Resident A and Resident A became
disappointed when he learned that he could not wear personal clothes and keep his
cell phone. Staff person 1 stated he told Resident A and Department of Health and
Human Service worker 1 and 2 that Resident A could only keep 1 bag of belongings.
Staff person 1 stated he completed the intake questions and afterwards offered
Resident A some food and took him to his unit. Staff person 1 was asked if he heard
staff in the multipurpose room talking and using profanity during the intake. Staff
person 1 stated he heard Staff person 2, 3, and 4 talking loudly with profanity. Staff
person 1 stated the intake room door was shut but not fully closed.
Staff person 2
I interviewed Staff person 2 in person on 07/28/2020. Staff person 2 stated Staff
person 1 completed Resident A’s intake because an intake was already completed
on his shift and Resident A arrived close to the end of his shift on 07/14/2020. Staff
person 2 stated he sat in the multipurpose room which is directly outside of the
intake room. Staff person 2 stated he talked with his coworkers as they waited to
punch out. Staff person 2 stated the conversation was not loud and profanity was not
used.
Staff person 3
I interviewed Staff person 3 in person on 07/28/2020. Staff person 3 stated Staff
person 1 was assigned Resident A’s intake on 07/14/2020 because Staff person 3
completed an intake earlier that day and Resident A arrived close to the end of his
shift. Staff person 3 stated he sat in the multipurpose room with his coworkers during
the intake. Staff person 3 denied being loud or using profanity while in the
multipurpose room.
Staff person 4
I interviewed Staff person 4 by telephone on 07/28/2020. Staff person 4 stated she
waited for her ride at the end of the shift in the multipurpose room with other
coworkers on 07/14/2020. Staff person 4 stated they sat at a table and conversed in
an everyday tone and did not use profanity.
4

Personnel records
I reviewed Staff person 1, 2, 3 and 4’s personnel file on 07/28/2020. None contained
discipline issues related to this complaint.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
ANALYSIS: Staff person 1 facilitated Resident A’s intake in a straightforward
manner. Although Staff person 2, 3 and 4 denied speaking
loudly and using profanity while in the multipurpose room it was
heard by Staff person 1, Resident A and Department of Health
and Human Service worker 1 and 2. It is found that Resident A’s
intake was not completed in a desirable setting. Staff also serve
as role models and the use of appropriate language is expected
on facility grounds.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ALLEGATION:
Resident A was not permitted to keep and wear his personal clothing at Clarence
Fischer Center.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident A
I interviewed Resident A in person on 07/28/2020. I asked Resident A about the
dress code at Clarence Fischer Center. Resident A stated the facility provided the
black sweatshirt and sweatpants, black socks, and flip flops he was wearing.
Resident A stated residents are not allowed to wear personal clothes.
5

Department of Health and Human Service worker 1 and 2
I interviewed Department of Health and Human Service (DHHS) worker 1 by
telephone on 07/22/2020. DHHS worker 1 stated Staff person 1 told Resident A
during the intake that he would receive a jumpsuit and crocs to wear. This was
comment was supported by DHHS worker 2.
Administrator 1
I interviewed Administrator 1 by telephone on 07/27/2020. Administrator 1 stated the
facility’s policy is for residents to wear provided sweatshirts and sweatpants and not
their personal clothes. Residents are not provided jumpsuits to wear.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 499.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing; storage space.
(1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of
the following:
(c) The method for ensuring that each resident has
sufficient clean, properly fitting, seasonal clothing.
ANALYSIS: I observed Resident A on 07/28/2020 wearing clean and
appropriately sized black sweatshirt and sweatpants, black
socks, and flip flops. It is not a licensing or contractual violation
for a facility to provide residents a uniform like wardrobe in place
of his personal clothing.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDING:
INVESTIGATION:
Staff person 1
I interviewed Staff person 1 in person on 07/28/2020. I asked Staff person 1 if he
was trained to be to complete intakes. Staff person 1 stated he was trained to
facilitate a resident’s intake when he became a Safety and Security Team staff
person.
Personnel file
I reviewed Staff person 1’s personnel file on 07/28/2020. Staff person 1 became a
Safety Security Team staff person in 03/2020. The Safety Security Team job
description does not list intakes but includes the responsibility of “task and duties are
subject to change to meet the needs of program.” Staff person 1’s training
documentation does not show Staff person 1 completed Safety Security Team
training or intake training.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 499.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program for new
employees. Job shadowing shall not be the only form of
orientation.
ANALYSIS: Staff person 1 became a Safety and Security Team staff person
in 03/2020. Staff person 1’s training documentation does not
support he was trained in his new job as a Safety and Security
Team staff person and trained to facilitate intakes. It is found
that Staff person 1 was not provided orientation in his new
position as a Safety and Security Team staff person and how to
facilitate intakes.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The continuance of a regular license is recommended for Clarence Fischer Center
upon receipt of an approved corrective action plan.
